Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Story: I was on my lunch break, sitting in the delivery van, when my phone buzzed with a message from my mom: “Can you call? Dad’s not feeling well.” I knew she wanted me to check in, to ask if everything was okay at home, to be the supportive son she could lean on. I started dialing her number, but just then, my work phone rang. It was a customer, her voice tense, asking about her package that was supposed to arrive an hour ago. I remembered the mix-up at the warehouse—her delivery was delayed, and I needed to explain the situation calmly and professionally, even though I could sense her frustration building. My mom’s call was still waiting. I felt torn, my chest tight. My parents needed me to be present, to show I cared. My job demanded I be courteous and focused, even when things went wrong. Both voices—my mother’s worried, the customer’s impatient—pulled at me, and I sat there, phone in each hand, not sure which role to answer first.
